comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Based on the bow planes and masts, I'm almost certain this is the E-1, which participated in a fleet review in the North River before Secretary of the Navy George von L. Meyer on the date this photo was taken. I'm guessing the other photos in this series were taken at the same fleet review. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_E-1_(SS-24)

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks!  We'll include a "probably"  in the new subject note, but your guess makes sense to us, too, after looking at the related photos  and your Wikipedia citation.

comment.author: 77032480@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Submarinos/Submarines/UBOOT, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group.

comment.author: 22968943@N05
comment._content: E-1 and -2 appear in this list of ships from the 1912 review: www.geocities.com/scs028a/1912List.html

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content:
The E-2 had a slightly different configuration of masts which is why I think this is the E-1. It's certainly an E series and there were only two of them so it has to be one or the other.

The E series were notable for having Edison cell batteries. These are based on Nickel/Iron chemistry. They were actually faster submerged (11 knots) than the far more advanced WWII fleet submarines (9 knots).

comment.author: 37308532@N08
comment._content: If this is the E-1, in 1912, on parade for President Taft, then it is likely that the person standing in the bridge to the aft is (then) Lt Chester W. Nimitz

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Good catch! I was so intent on identifying the equipment I didn't even notice who was in command.
